transcribedText: What I want to do today, since this is Build as a Startup School, is share with you some lessons I've learned about building startups at AI Fund. AI Fund is a venture studio, and we build an average of about one startup per month. And because we co-found the startups, we're in there writing code, talking to customers, designing our features, determining pricing. And so we've done a lot of reps of not just watching others build startups, but actually being in the weeds, building startups with entrepreneurs. And what I want to do today is share with you some of the lessons I've learned building startups, especially around this changing AI technology and what it enables. And we focus on the theme of speed. So it turns out that for those of you that want to build a startup, I think a strong predictor for startups' odds of success is execution speed. And I have a lot of respect for the entrepreneurs and executives that can just do things really quickly. And new AI technology is enabling startups to go much faster. So what I hope to do is share with you some of those best practices, which are frankly changing every two to three months still, to let you get that speed that hopefully lets you have a higher odds of success. Before diving into speed, a lot of people ask me, hey Andrew, where are the opportunities for startups? So this is what I think of as an AI stack, where at the lowest level are the semiconductor companies, then the clouds are hyperscalers built on top of that, a lot of the AI foundation model companies built on top of that, and even though a lot of PR excitement and hype has been on these technology layers, it turns out that almost by definition, the biggest opportunities have to be at the application layer, because we actually need the applications to generate even more revenue so that they can afford to pay the foundation, cloud and semiconductor technology layers. So for whatever reason, media and social media tends not to talk about the application layer as much. But for those of you thinking of building startups, almost by definition, the biggest opportunities have to be there, although of course, the opportunities are all layers of the stack. One of the things that's changed a lot over the last year, and in terms of AI tech trends, if you ask me what's the most important tech trend in AI, I would say it's the rise of agentic AI. And about a year and a half ago, when I started to go around and give talks to try to convince people that AI agents might be a thing, I did not realize that around last summer, a bunch of marketers would get a hold of this term and use it as a sticker and slap it on everything in sight, which made it almost lose some of its meaning. But I want to share with you from a technical perspective, why I think agentic AI is exciting and important and also opens up a lot more startup opportunities. So it turns out that the way a lot of us use OMs is to prompt it, to have it generate output. And the way we have an OOM output something is as if you're going to a human, or in this case an AI, and asking it to please type out an essay for you by writing from the first word to the last word.

slides.title: Introduction to Startup Lessons
slides.content: Today, I'll share lessons learned from building startups at AI Fund, a venture studio producing about one startup per month. We co-found these startups, engaging directly in development and strategy.
slides.speakerNotes: AI Fund is actively involved in the startup process, making us both observers and participants in startup creation.

slides.title: The Importance of Execution Speed
slides.content: A key predictor of startup success is execution speed. New AI technologies are enabling faster startup development, offering a competitive edge.
slides.speakerNotes: Emphasize the importance of speed in execution and highlight how AI is facilitating rapid development for startups.

slides.title: Opportunities in the AI Stack
slides.content: The AI stack includes semiconductors, cloud services, AI foundation models, and applications. Despite hype around technology layers, the biggest opportunities lie in application development.
slides.speakerNotes: Discuss the AI stack's structure and the reasons why applications represent the most significant opportunity.

slides.title: AI Tech Trends: Rise of Agentic AI
slides.content: Agentic AI has become a significant trend, with potential startup opportunities. Despite the term being overused, it holds technical promise.
slides.speakerNotes: Explain why agentic AI is an exciting trend and how it differs from traditional AI applications.

slides.title: Agentic AI: Technical Insights
slides.content: Agentic AI involves interaction with AI models, prompting them to generate output, much like instructing a human to write an essay.
slides.speakerNotes: Clarify the functionality of agentic AI as an interactive process, offering new ways for startups to leverage AI technology.

slides.title: Conclusion and Best Practices
slides.content: AI technology is rapidly evolving, changing best practices every few months. Embrace speed and innovation to increase startup success odds.
slides.speakerNotes: Reiterate the dynamic nature of AI and encourage embracing new practices to maintain a competitive edge in startup development.
